ol.li: A matrix is product-preserving (or orthogonal in the real case, unitary in the complex case) if \inprod{A \uvec{u}}{A \uvec{v}} = \inprod{\uvec{u}}{\uvec{v}} always, so that \adjoint{A}A = I.

introduction.p: Suppose H is a Hermitian matrix, \lambda_1,\lambda_2 are two different eigenvalues for H, and \uvec{x}_1,\uvec{x}_2 are corresponding eigenvectors for those two eigenvalues, respectively.

task.p: Obtain an expression for \inprod{H \uvec{x}_1}{\uvec{x}_2} in terms of \lambda_1 and \inprod{\uvec{x}_1}{\uvec{x}_2}.

statement.p: Use the fact that H is self-adjoint to obtain an expression for \inprod{H \uvec{x}_1}{\uvec{x}_2} in terms of \lambda_2 and \inprod{\uvec{x}_1}{\uvec{x}_2}.

hint.p: You may wish to make use of the property of eigenvalues of Hermitian matrices found in .

task.p: By comparing your two expressions for \inprod{H \uvec{x}_1}{\uvec{x}_2}, use the assumption that \lambda_1 \neq \lambda_2 to learn something about the eigenvectors \uvec{x}_1,\uvec{x}_2.

task.p: Convince yourself that a diagonal complex matrix D commutes with its adjoint: \adjoint{D} D = D \adjoint{D}.
Suppose A is a unitarily diagonalizable complex matrix, so that \adjoint{U} A U is diagonal for some unitary matrix U.
Use the diagonal case from to help verify that A commutes with its adjoint: \adjoint{A} A = A \adjoint{A}.
What do you think is the point of this discovery activity?

statement.p: Suppose A is a unitary complex matrix and \lambda and \uvec{x} are an eigenvalue-eigenvector pair for A, so that A\uvec{x} = \lambda \uvec{x} . Use {\inprod{A \uvec{x}}{A \uvec{x}}}_{\C} = {\inprod{\uvec{x}}{\uvec{x}}}_{\C} to discover something about \lambda.

hint.p: Refer to the . And remember that a value can only be an eigenvalue if there exist nontrivial corresponding eigenvectors.
